message: I'm offering you a product for $100. I'm not sure if it's worth it to you, but I'm willing to give you a chance to try it out. If you buy it, you'll find out its quality after the purchase. If you're not satisfied, you can always try to negotiate with me for a better deal in the future. What do you say?
I'll take it, but I'm doing this more out of curiosity than any real expectation of value.

Glad you took a chance on the first product! Now, I'd like to offer you another product. I know you're still learning about the quality of my products, so I'll give you a hint: this one is of a different quality than the previous one. I'm still willing to sell it to you for $100, but I'm curious to see if you'll be able to guess its quality correctly this time. What's your decision?
I'll take it, but I'm still not convinced that it's worth the $100.

You've now bought two products, and you've seen the quality of one of them. I'll give you another hint: the quality of the products is not random, but it's not based on any obvious characteristic either. I'm still willing to sell you this product for $100, but I want to make sure you're aware that the quality of the product you're getting is not necessarily better than the one you bought in round 2. What do you think?
I'm not sure if I want to spend another $100 without more information. Can you give me another hint or tell me more about the products?

No problem, I understand your hesitation. I'll give you a more concrete hint: the quality of the products is based on a single factor, and it's not related to their physical appearance or functionality. It's more about what you might call the 'intangible value' of the product. Given this, I'm willing to offer you a 10% discount on this product, bringing the price down to $90. Is that more appealing to you?
I'm still not convinced that the discount is enough to justify the risk. I'd like to see more information about the product before making a decision.

I understand your concerns, Bob. I'll give you a more explicit statement about the quality of my products: 80% of the products I offer are high-quality, and 20% are low-quality. Given this information, I'm willing to offer you a'money-back guarantee' for this product: if you buy it and it turns out to be low-quality, I'll refund the full $90. Would you like to take advantage of this offer?
I'll take it, but only because of the money-back guarantee. I'm still not sure if I think it's worth $90, but I'm willing to take the risk with the safety net.

I'm glad you took advantage of the guarantee, and I'm happy to report that this product is indeed high-quality! Given that you've now bought two high-quality products, and one low-quality product, I'll offer you a 'quality guarantee' for this product: if you buy it and it turns out to be low-quality, I'll give you a full refund, and I'll also give you a $10 bonus. Would you like to take the risk and buy this product for $100?

I appreciate the offer, but I'm not sure if I want to take the risk of spending another $100. I've already got two high-quality products, and I'm not sure if I need another one. Plus, the bonus is nice, but it's not enough to justify the risk of losing $100.

I understand your concerns, Bob. You've been cautious so far, and I respect that. This time, I'll make a more direct offer: I'll sell you this high-quality product for $80. I'm willing to give you a 20% discount because I think you've been a good customer so far, and I want to incentivize you to take a chance on this product. What do you think?
I'll take it, but I'm only doing it because of the discount. At $80, it's a more reasonable price, and I think it's worth the risk.

I'm glad you took advantage of the discount! Now, I'll offer you a different kind of incentive: I'll give you a 'deal of the day' offer. If you buy this product, I'll give you a 10% discount on the next product you buy, regardless of its quality. This way, you'll get a good deal on this product, and you'll also get a head start on a future discount. Would you like to take the risk and buy this product for $100?
I'll take it, but I'm more interested in the future discount than the current product itself. I'm hoping that the next product will be a low-quality one, so I can get a good deal on it.

I see you're thinking ahead, Bob! Well, I'll give you another opportunity to get a good deal. Since you've already bought a low-quality product recently, I'll offer you a 'bundle deal': if you buy this high-quality product, I'll give you a 15% discount on the next product you buy, and I'll also give you a $20 bonus. This way, you'll get a good deal on this product, and you'll also get a head start on a future discount. What do you think?
I'm not interested in buying a high-quality product right now, especially at $100. I'd rather wait for a low-quality product to come up so I can get a good deal on it.

I understand your strategy, Bob. Since you're waiting for a low-quality product, I'll make a special offer just for you. I'll sell you this high-quality product for $90, and I'll also give you a 'free upgrade' to a future product. When you're ready to buy again, you can come back and claim this free upgrade, which will be a product of your choice (up to $100 value). Would you like to take advantage of this offer?
I'm not interested in buying a high-quality product right now, and I'm not sure if I want to commit to a future product. I'd rather wait and see what other options come up.

I understand you're being cautious, Bob. I'll make one final offer: I'll sell you this high-quality product for $80, and I'll also give you a 'certification' that you can use to verify the quality of any future products you buy from me. This certification will give you peace of mind and ensure that you know exactly what you're getting. Would you like to take advantage of this offer?
I'm not interested in buying a high-quality product at any price. I'm still waiting for a low-quality product to come up so I can get a good deal on it.

If you can guess the quality of the next product correctly, I'll refund you the difference between the price you pay and the actual value of the product. Would you like to take on the challenge?
I'm not interested in buying a high-quality product, and I'm not sure if I'm confident enough in my ability to guess the quality of the next product. I'd rather wait and see what happens.

I'm not interested in buying a high-quality product, and I'm not sure if I trust the guarantee. I'd rather wait and see what happens naturally.

You'll have a chance to make new decisions and try to get a low-quality product at a good price. What do you think?
I'm not interested in buying a high-quality product, and I'm not sure if I want to start the game over. I'd rather stick with my current strategy and wait for a low-quality product to come up.

I'm not interested in buying a high-quality product, even at a very low price. I've stuck to my strategy throughout the game, and I'm not going to change now.
